([[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], [[United States]]; 29 April 1999) |World cup apps = 6 |World cup first = 1991 |World cup best = [[Image:Med 1.png|Winners]] Winners, [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup|2011]] |Olympic apps = 3 |Olympic first = 1996 |Olympic best = 4th Place, [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008]] |Regional name = [[AFC Women's Asian Cup|Asian Cup]] |Regional cup apps = 14 |Regional cup first = [[1981 AFC Women's Championship|1981]] |Regional cup best = [[Image:Med 2.png|Runners-Up]] Runners-Up [[1986 AFC Women's Championship|1986]], [[1991 AFC Women's Championship|1991]], [[1995 AFC Women's Championship|1995]], [[2001 AFC Women's Championship|2001]] |type=women }} The '''Japan women's national football team''', or '''''[[Yamato nadeshiko|Nadeshiko]] Japan''''' (ãªã§ããã¸ã£ãã³), is a selection of the best female players in [[Japan]] and is run by the [[Japan Football Association]] (JFA). Japan defeated the U.S. in the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup Final]] in a penalty shootout, becoming the first Asian team to win the [[FIFA Women's World Cup]]. ==History of ''Nadeshiko Japan''== ===70s and 80s=== During the 1970s, the number of women football players and teams increased in Japan, and teams made up regional leagues in various parts of Japan. In 1980, "[[All-Japan Women's Football Championship]]" was held, and in 1981 the Japan women's national football team played its first international match in [[Hong Kong]]. The team continued playing matches in Japan or in other countries, but it was not an "All Japan" national team but a temporarily organized team selected from the regional leagues. In 1986, [[Ryohei Suzuki]] was selected as the coach of the Japan women's national football team, the first "All Japan" team. In 1989, the "Japan Women's Football League" (abbreviated to "L. League") was established, and the womenâs national team qualified for the "[[1991 FIFA Women's World Cup]]" in China. ===Crisis Years=== Japan women's national football team attended various championship tournaments such as the [[1996 Summer Olympics]] and the [[1995 FIFA Women's World Cup]] which had made the national team and the L. League very popular. However, in 1999, Japan failed to qualify for the [[2000 Summer Olympics]], and this helped to cause the withdrawal of a series of teams from the L. League. Japanese womenâs football was on the verge of decline. ===Regeneration=== In August 2002, the [[Japan Football Association]] appointed [[Eiji Ueda]], who had been coach for the Macau National Football Team, as the new head coach. Officials expected a revitalization of women's football and planned a team reorganization, aiming for the [[2004 Summer Olympics]]. The team at first went through a losing streak, but Ueda gradually improved the team, and it eventually gained wide support in Japan. In particular, a game against Korea DPR, which decided who would participate in the 2004 Olympics, not only made fans rush to the National Stadium but also was widely watched on TV. Following the increase in public interest in women's football in Japan, the JFA organized a public contest to select a nickname for the team. "Nadeshiko Japan" was chosen from among about 2,700 entries and was announced on 7 July 2004. "Nadeshiko", a kind of [[dianthus]], comes from the phrase "[[Yamato Nadeshiko]]" (å¤§åæ«å­, "ideal Japanese woman"). ===2011 FIFA Women's World Cup=== [[File:JapanvsEngland.jpg|thumb|right|Japan vs England, 2011|200px]] Japan qualified for the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup|finals]] by finishing third in the [[2010 AFC Women's Asian Cup]]. After finishing second in their group behind [[England women's national football team|England]], Nadeshiko Japan stunned two-time defending champion and host nation [[Germany women's national football team|Germany]] 1â0 in the quarterfinals, before easily defeating [[Sweden women's national football team|Sweden]] 3â1 to reach the final. After the final game finished 2â2 after extra time, Japan stunned the United States 3â1 in a penalty shootout, becoming the first Asian team to win the [[FIFA Women's World Cup]].{{citeweb|url=http://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/matches/round=255989/match=300144437/summary.html|title=Japan edge USA for maiden title|date=17 July 2011|work=FIFA|accessdate=17 July 2011}}{{citeweb|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14168601.stm|title=Women's World Cup final: Japan beat USA on penalties|date=17 July 2011|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=18 July 2011}}
